newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay exchange plans to go on-line in 100 cities.
newsitem.headline: Bombay exchange plans to go on-line in 100 cities.

text.p: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) said on Friday it plans to extend its online trading system to 100 cities in June, subject to Department of Telecommunications (DoT) clearance.
"We expect to get DoT clearance on Monday, then within 15 days we will start installing the system at different sites," BSE," M.G. Damani, president of the BSE, said.
"We shall cover 100 cities within the month of June," Damani said, adding that it depended on DoT approval.
He also said the BSE will stop charging member brokers a 250,000 rupee admission fee if they convert to corporate entities.
Around 440 of the 531 active BSE card holders were either sole-ownership brokerages or partnerships.
"I expect at least 400 of these to corporatise," he said.

Damani said this move was taken to act in line with concessions made in the 1997/98 budget passed by parliament earlier this month, and added that he would seek further concessions from The Securities and Exchange Borad of India (SEBI).
